Quoting Anil and Rita Philip <anil_rita@...>:

> I shall try to explain more clearly:
> 
> if(some condition is true) {
> 	do some work;
> 	return result1;
> }
> else {
> 	do some other work;
> 	return result2;
> }
> 
> Here are two execution paths within a procedure. Both
> result1 and result2 might be identical in value some
> of the time, for a many to one function. Using Junit,
> how can one know that both paths have been exercised
> or tested? 

If you're performing codepath analysis and verification after code has been 
written, then use JUnit like you'd use any other testing tool or technique. The 
only way to know whether the codepath are exercised is to exercise them with 
known values that cause each path to be executed the desired number of times. 
JUnit is not a codepath analysis tool; it is a tool for expressing black-box 
tests at the class level.

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
